content: It seems strange to me that we have both https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Limits/Shapes/FunctorToTypes.html and https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Limits/FunctorToTypes.html; they're both small files claiming to be covering similar ground (concrete implementations of (co)limits in (co)-presheaf categories)
We should probably only have one of them, and maybe renamed to Presheaf; opinions on which and whether?
(This has come up because I'd like to add the general isomorphism of (co)-products of presheaves to pointwise (co)-products in Type, and I don't know where to put it!)

No, Limits.* is for general limits/colimits, while Limits.Shapes.* is for definitions/lemmas that are specific to specific shapes like binary products, pushouts, etc. FunctorToTypes is good because presheaves would refer specifically to contravariant functors.
Regarding coproducts of presheaves and pointwise coproducts, mathlib already knows that (evaluation _ _).obj _ preserves colimits/limits, and in principle, this is all we need.

Joël Riou said:

No, Limits.* is for general limits/colimits, while Limits.Shapes.* is for definitions/lemmas that are specific to specific shapes like binary products, pushouts, etc. FunctorToTypes is good because presheaves would refer specifically to contravariant functors.

We already use "Foo" to mean "Foo and Cofoo" in filenames in the category theory library, though; using "Presheaf" to mean "Presheaves and Copresheaves" wouldn't be anything new. I'm also not entirely sure it makes sense to split up tiny files like that, but I'll table that for now.

Regarding coproducts of presheaves and pointwise coproducts, mathlib already knows that (evaluation _ _).obj _ preserves colimits/limits, and in principle, this is all we need.

I mean, I wrote them because it made another library feature much easier to implement, specifically u-filtered colimits in Quiv.{v, u}, which is done by using an equivalence to a presheaf category anyway so using the pointwise concrete coproduct makes things a lot easier. Probably it can be rewritten to avoid that, but I'm not sure there's a good reason for it?
